In October 2013, when Russell Brand declared on Newsnight that he had never voted, not out of apathy but “out of absolute indifference and weariness”, Denise Felkin noticed a ripple of agreement among her friends on social media. Doing an MA in photojournalism at the time, she was looking for a politically relevant idea for her final major project and I’m not voting because… is the result: portraits of people aged 17 to 71 who, for varying reasons, don’t – or won’t – vote.

“[I wanted] to create a photographic historic record of a political movement that hasn’t been widely publicised and to give a human face to the nonconformists,” Felkin explains. She discovered it was easy to find non-voters for the project: “I’d turn up to someone’s house to take a photo of them and other people there would say, ‘Oh, that’s me as well.’” After photographing around 20 people, she chose just nine for the series; a hat-tip to the German nein, “to represent a ‘no’”.

Felkin, 47, voted aged 18 and again in 2010, but admits there were many elections in between when she didn’t. For her, and some of her subjects, not voting is a political stance in itself. “Roger feels about it really strongly, so much so that he would go to the polling station and spoil his paper,” she tells me. I ask Roger about this, and he says: “I am going to vote, but I’m just going to put ‘none of the above’.” Laura feels similarly. “I think striking them all is a brilliant idea. It’s a start to breaking up the system – it might be something for people to think about next time. A lot of people this time are doing strategic voting just to get the Tories out, but I went out with an Etonian when I was a teenager who had two uncles who were politicians, and I’ve come to realise that Lib Dem, Labour, they’re all from the same old boys’ club, and we have to trust them but we can’t.”

This complete lack of trust in politicians is the main thing the people I speak to from Felkin’s project have in common. They uniformly feel let down, whether that’s due to benefit cuts, the housing crisis, or cuts to the NHS. “Politicians go on TV and say, ‘We can give you this, we can give you that’ and make false promises they can’t keep,” says Sam, who can’t work due to mental health problems and who had her benefits cut.

Not one of them doesn’t get passionate talking about politics – this isn’t apathy; it’s frustration. They feel that not voting is their last resort. “If more people spoil their paper when they vote, eventually, an MP’s got to have the common sense to address that and think: why?” says Roger. Laura suggests an alternative to what she sees as the outdated way government works. “It would be really good if we could vote on aspects of politics that interested us on our smartphones.”

But it’s not just those who can vote who Felkin photographed. She feels under-18s are too often left out of politics, and wanted to redress that by including them in her project. “When you talk to younger people, for example Amos, or Rhiannon and Pariss, they just don’t care about voting and they haven’t been taught about it at school.”

She points out that Junior, who is unable to speak, bought his “WTF” T-shirt especially for the shoot to symbolise his stance: even though he is too young to vote, he says he wouldn’t anyway.

Now based between Brighton and Colchester, Felkin spent her coming-of-age years in Tamworth in the 80s, pogoing to the Sex Pistols and learning about Thatcher’s government through The Young Ones, Spitting Image and Not the Nine O’Clock News. It’s an era that has inadvertently informed her work ever since. When, in the mid‑90s, she was studying for her fine art degree in Sunderland, “my tutor said that my work always had this real 80s feel about it… I felt that was a bit of a criticism back then, but when I came to my project this time, I thought, ‘Actually, it’s not such a bad thing – that makes it personal.’” Inspired by artists such as Manet, Felkin likes her photos to have painterly qualities, and admires the work of London-based photographer Tom Hunter.

A few months ago, Felkin was uncertain if she was going to vote this year, but the project has made up her mind: “I wouldn’t want to not vote, and then the Conservatives get back in again,” she says, although she still empathises with people who have no interest in voting. “In a way, politics is a bit like religion, isn’t it? You either believe or don’t believe.”

‘I never have. I’ve always realised that it’s pointless’
